heading: 2.7 Standardizing data
text:
â€™ve mean centered data, can go one step divide standard deviation. results something often called z-score. process converting variables original units z-scores called standardizing data.\[
Z = \frac{\left(X - \overline{X}\right)}{SD(X)}
\]useful? One reason remove units measurement facilitate comparisons variables. Suppose \(X\) represents height inches. numerator (\(X - \overline{X}\)) units inches. standard deviation \(SD(X)\) also units inches. divide, units go away z-score left without units, sometimes called â€œdimensionless quantityâ€.Suppose female United States 6 feet tall (72 inches). Suppose female China 5â€™8 tall (68 inches). absolute terms, American woman taller Chinese woman. â€™re interested knowing woman taller relative respective population?mean height American woman 65â€ standard deviation 3.5â€ mean height Chinese woman 62â€ standard deviation 2.5â€. (numbers arenâ€™t perfectly correct, â€™re probably close-ish.)Calculate z-scores women.woman taller relative population?Although z-scores donâ€™t technically units, can think measuring many standard deviations value lies mean.z-score value equals mean?meaning negative z-score?z-score American woman 2. means height measures two standard deviations mean.real-world data, use technology . temperature measurements New York 1974. (daily highs across six-month period.)calculate mean standard deviation:average high 78 degrees Fahrenheit standard deviation 9.5 degrees Fahrenheit.just subtract mean, get mean-centered data.also divide standard deviation, get standardized variable (set z-scores). Note extra parentheses make sure get order operations right. subtract first, divide whole mean-centered quantity standard deviation.easier way R use scale command. (Sorry, output little long. Keep scrolling .)Although outputs formatted little differently, can go back check sets numbers match .mean standardized variable? know ?Letâ€™s calculate variance standardized variable. , â€™ll note mean \(\overline{X}\) just number. Also, standard deviation \(SD(X)\) just number. make calculation easier understand, letâ€™s just substitute letters easier work :\(M = \overline{X}\)\(S = SD(X)\)Remember, \(M\) \(S\) constants.Now need calculate \(Var(Z)\). â€™ll first couple steps. take , using variance rules earlier chapter, simplify expression get numerical answer. sure justify step citing rule invoked get .\[\begin{align}
Var(Z) &= Var\left(\frac{\left(X - \overline{X}\right)}{SD(X)}\right) \\
    &= Var\left(\frac{\left(X - M\right)}{S}\right) \\
    &= Var\left(\frac{1}{S}\left(X - M\right)\right) \\
    &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]get answer 1. standardized variable always variance 1. important fact future chapters.

heading: 3.3 Covariance rules
text:
â€™ll think variance covariance rules one big list. left Rule 4, now â€™ll introduce Rule 5.Rule 5\[
Cov(X, X) = Var(X)
\]words, Rule 5 states covariance variable just thing variance variable. quite remarkable! means variance really just special case covariance.Explain Rule 5 true. (Hint: think calculate \(Cov(X, X)\) using either formula tableâ€”!)Rule 6\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{1}\right)
\]words, say covariance symmetric.Explain Rule 6 true. (, think formula tableâ€”!)next four rules analogous similar rules variance (Rule 1, Rule 2, Rule 3, Rule 4).Rule 7Suppose \(C\) â€œconstantâ€ variable, meaning always value (rather variable contain lots different numbers). ,\[
Cov\left(X, C\right) = 0
\]always, try explain rule. Give intuitive explanation rule â€œâ€ true. think computationally, thinking either formula tableâ€”!Rule 8\[
Cov\left(X_{1} + X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) + Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]appreciate longer restriction relationships among variables involved. Rule 2 worked two variables independent. hand, Rule 8 works combination variables, matter relation.Even satisfying next rule:Rule 9\[
Cov\left(X_{1} - X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) - Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Yay! minus sign behaves sensibly now! course, since covariances can positive negative (unlike variances always positive!) can safely subtract two without worry. rule, like Rule 8, depend \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent. can two variables.versions rules addition subtraction side, just minor variations Rule 8 Rule 9, â€™re worth mentioning separate rule. Remember covariance symmetric, can always swap things left right comma.\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2} \pm X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) \pm Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Rule 10If \(\) number,\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) =  Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)  
\]rule also sensible. Instead Rule 4 takes number \(\) pulls \(^{2}\), Rule 10 just pulls single factor \(\) (either slot).Just couple rules. talking independence conjunction Rule 8 Rule 9. leads directly interesting super-important rule:Rule 11If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = 0
\]Rule 11 true, intuitively?â€™s interesting note rule works one way. words, know two variables independent, can conclude covariance zero. However, know covariance zero, doesnâ€™t necessarily mean two variables independent. â€™ll see example later chapter.Finally, one rule rule :Rule 12For two variables \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\):\[
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) =
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]brings practically everything know together one rule!Proving Rule 12 give us good practice type manipulation â€™ll need future chapters. goes. first steps, name rule â€™re invoking. , â€™ll pick thread follow last steps .\[\begin{align}
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) &= Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, aX_{1} + bX_{2}) \\
    &= Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, aX_{1}) + Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, bX_{2}) \\
    &=  Cov(aX_{1}, aX_{1}) +
        Cov(bX_{2}, aX_{1}) + \\
    &   \qquad Cov(aX_{1}, bX_{2}) +
        Cov(bX_{2}, bX_{2}) \\
    &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]â€™ll need rules calculations future chapters. Rather search Chapter 2 chapter, â€™ve gathered rules one convenient place Appendix .

pros cons calculating covariance similar variance. mathematics much nicer covariance, lose interpretability.Letâ€™s suppose \(X_{1}\) measures salary dollars \(X_{2}\) measures years education. expect association variables, calculate covariance. unit measurement resulting number?solution problem simple variance. Since variance squared units, take square root. Likewise, makes sense divide number expressed years leave us just dollars.solution dilemma accept arenâ€™t going able keep units meaningful way. Therefore, want something standardized, meaning units.\(X_{1}\) expressed dollars, can think statistic measures spread also units dollars?Likewise, \(X_{2}\) measured years, statistic measures spread also units years?previous activity gives us idea. divide covariance standard deviation \(X_{1}\) standard deviation \(X_{2}\)?\[

\]Sometimes â€™s written like :\[

\]

Corr(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]

r_{X_{1}X_{2}}

text:
last chapter, showed variance standardized variable 1. covariance two standardized variables?Letâ€™s standardize \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\). make math little easier, â€™ll use similar notation used end last chapter.\(M_{1} = \overline{X_{1}}\)\(S_{1} = SD(X_{1})\)\(M_{2} = \overline{X_{2}}\)\(S_{2} = SD(X_{2})\)â€™ll write z-scores way amenable mathematical manipulation (like ):\[

\]\[

Cov(Z_{1}, Z_{2}) &= Cov\left( \frac{1}{S_{1}}\left(X_{1} - M_{1}\right), \frac{1}{S_{2}}\left(X_{2} - M_{2}\right) \right) \\

\end{align}\]Work . Take time. Apply rules carefully. know â€™re aiming , get\[
Cov(Z_{1}, Z_{2}) = \frac{Cov\left( X_{1}, X_{2} \right)}{S_{1} S_{2}}
\]Okay, now remember \(S_{1}\) just convenient substitute \(SD(X_{1})\) \(S_{2}\) just substitute \(SD(X_{2})\). Wait, answer look familiar?cool! Correlation simply covariance two variables â€™ve standardized.also reinforces earlier comment interpreting covariance removing extraneous influence spread individual variables. \[

\]
bounded -1 1?Letâ€™s go back standardized variable keep things simple. correlation just covariance two standardized variables:\[

\]Use rules calculate :\[
Var(Z_{1} + Z_{2})
\]Remember \(Z_{1}\) \(Z_{2}\) necessarily independent. (fact, hope . Otherwise, care correlation? zero!) need Rule 12, Rule 2. Keep manipulating get
\[
2 + 2Corr(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]Since variances always non-negative, now know \[

\]
Solve inequality \(Corr(X_{1}, X_{2})\).Now follow exact steps

\]little change answer, one small change. , solve resulting inequality. (Donâ€™t forget key rule working inequalities multiplying dividing negative number changes direction inequality.)fact state without proof:Correlation interpretable strength linear associations.? Basically, boils fact â€œperfectâ€ correlation 1 -1 achievable data points lie perfectly straight line. heading: 4.2 Regression terminology
text: one variable suspect may help us predict another variable, one way study using simple regression model.related , somewhat different , covariance. Covariance symmetric, expresses idea two variables mutually related. â€œdirectionalityâ€ relationship. way contrast, simple regression model asserts one variables â€œexplanatoryâ€ â€œresponseâ€. words, start values properties explanatory variable try deduce can values properties response variable.Keep mind â€œdirectionalityâ€ â€œcausalityâ€. â€™s possible one variable causes another, needs data collection process (often carefully controlled experiment) clear scientific rationale justifies causal relationship variables can start thinking inferring causality. purposes much book, directionality just means wish establish predictive relationship wherein start properties one variable try predict properties another variable. often â€œsensibleâ€ order based research questions asked hypotheses posed.many different terminological conventions statistics, aware â€œexplanatoryâ€ variables also calledâ€”often depending discipline contextâ€”predictors, features, covariates, controls, regressors, inputs, independent variables. fact, context structural equation modeling, use term â€œexogenousâ€ refer variables play role. (term much precise definition â€™ll discuss future chapters.) â€œresponseâ€ variables might called outcomes, outputs, targets, explained variables, dependent variables, among others. book, often use term â€œendogenousâ€ (, specific way yet explained). data collection process clear scientific rationale justifies causal relationship variables, might able refer variables either â€œcauseâ€ â€œeffectâ€.Keep mind â€™s scientific question want ask determines explanatory/response relationship. different researcher different hypothesis might use two variables roles reversed.anxiety/smart-phone example , variable explanatory response, least according way stated scenario?

code:
X <- airquality$Wind - mean(airquality$Wind)
Y <- airquality$Temp - mean(airquality$Temp)
airquality_mc <- tibble(X, Y)
airquality_mc## # A tibble: 153 Ã— 2
##        X      Y
##    <dbl>  <dbl>
##  1 -2.56 -10.9 
##  2 -1.96  -5.88
##  3  2.64  -3.88
##  4  1.54 -15.9 
##  5  4.34 -21.9 
##  6  4.94 -11.9 
##  7 -1.36 -12.9 
##  8  3.84 -18.9 
##  9 10.1  -16.9 
## 10 -1.36  -8.88
## # â€¦ with 143 more rows
ggplot(airquality_mc, aes(y = Y, x = X)) +
    geom_point()
ggplot(airquality_mc, aes(y = Y, x = X)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth(method = lm, se = FALSE)## `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'
ggplot(airquality_mc, aes(y = Y, x = X)) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth(method = lm, se = FALSE) +
    annotate("segment",
             x = -2.56, y = 3.15,
             xend = -2.56, yend = 3.15 - 14.03,
             color = "red", size = 1.5) +
    annotate("segment",
             x = 4.94, y = -6.08,
             xend = 4.94, yend = -6.08 + 9.20,
             color = "red", size = 1.5)## `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'

heading: 4.5 Calculating regression parameters
text:
Now â€™ll show one way calculate regression parameters (numbers) diagram. isnâ€™t way . fact, approach used intro stats classes. approach helpful illustrate way calculations future chapters.Letâ€™s go back diagram without numbers:letter \(v\) easy â€™s just variance \(X\):\[
Var(X) = v
\]can estimate directly data. (already R temperature wind speed data.) completing activities , also calculate \(b\) \(e\).get parameters, set equations.
first observation need make , important arrows diagram, â€™s just important arrows .arrows directly connecting \(X\) \(E\)? imply relationship \(X\) \(E\)? regression assumption related question?Given , \(Cov(X, E)\)?Next, \(Y\) combination \(X\) \(E\), â€™ve already seen can write\[
Y = bX + E
\]Therefore, can calculate \(Var(Y)\) according formula using established rules. (convenient list one place located Appendix .)Keep simplifying following much possible:\[\begin{align}
Var(Y)  &= Var(bX + E) \\
        &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]end \[
b^{2}v + e
\]Donâ€™t forget \(Var(X) = v\) \(Var(E) = e\) diagram!also need use information covariance \(X\) \(Y\). Keep simplifying calculation :\[\begin{align}
Cov(X, Y)  &= Cov(X, bX + E) \\
        &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]end \[
bv
\]Use R calculate \(Var(X)\), \(Var(Y)\) \(Cov(X, Y)\).get 12.4, 89.6, -15.3, respectively.Now can set equations need solve various letters want. three equations established:\[\begin{align}
12.4 &= v \\
89.6 &= b^2v + e \\
-15.3 &= bv
\end{align}\]Time little algebra. know \(v\). Using value, solve \(b\) first (using last equation). , using values \(b\) \(v\), solve \(e\) second equation.Check values got ones earlier diagram (possibility little rounding error).Now letâ€™s go , time, full generality:\[\begin{align}
Var(X) &= v \\
Var(Y) &= b^2v + e \\
Cov(X, Y) &= bv
\end{align}\]Therefore,\[
v = Var(X)
\]\[
b = \frac{Cov(X, Y)}{Var(X)}
\]\[
e = Var(Y) - \left( \frac{Cov(X, Y)}{Var(X)} \right)^2 Var(X)
\]

heading: 4.6 The model-implied matrix
4.7 Error variance in terms of correlation
text:
formulas derived fine far go. allow take quantities calculated data (variances covariances observed variables) translate estimates model parameters.formula error variance \(e\) little gross, though. little trickery, can simplify formula quite bit.starting point:\[
e = Var(Y) - \left( \frac{Cov(X, Y)}{Var(X)} \right)^2 Var(X)
\]Explain right-hand side can rewritten \[
Var(Y) - \frac{Cov(X, Y)^{2}}{Var(X)}
\]â€™re going multiply top bottom fraction right \(Var(Y)\):\[
Var(Y) - \frac{Cov(X, Y)^{2} Var(Y)}{Var(X) Var(Y)}
\]can factor common term \(Var(Y)\) pieces:\[
Var(Y) \left( 1 - \frac{Cov(X, Y)^{2}}{Var(X) Var(Y)} \right)
\]thing? words, new fraction right look familiar way?hope recognize fraction right just correlation coefficient squared. whole equation can now written \[
e = Var(Y) \left( 1 - r_{XY}^2 \right)
\]nice consequence last equation. term parentheses \(\left( 1 - r_{XY}^2 \right)\) number 0 1, right? Since multiplying variance \(Y\), can think term parentheses proportion. variance \(Y\) explained model one two ways. thick arrow coming left uses \(X\) predict variance \(Y\). rest variance \(Y\) left error term \(e\). Therefore, \(\left( 1 - r_{XY}^2 \right)\) proportion variance \(Y\) left error.true, must also case \(r_{XY}^2\) proportion variance \(Y\) explained \(X\). Calculating one minus proportion gives complementary proportion. example, \(\left( 1 - r_{XY}^2 \right) = 0.3\), 30% variance \(Y\) left error. implies 70% variance \(Y\) explained \(X\). \(1 - 0.3 = 0.7\).authors write \(R^{2}\) instead \(r^{2}\) reason.

heading: 4.8 Regression with standardized variables

text: straightforward way run regression R use lm command. stands â€œlinear modelâ€. uses special symbol, tilde ~, express relationship endogenous variable exogenous variable. endogenous (response) variable always goes left, tilde. exogenous (predictor) variable goes right, tilde. Finally, data argument tell lm find variables model.two numbers slope \(b\)?havenâ€™t talked intercept yet, according output, ? heading: 4.9.2 Using lavaan
text: also introduce briefly lavaan package. â€™s totally overkill simple regression, getting used syntax now make easier continue build confidence using tool use.lavaan model built similar way lm using tilde ~ notation. One big difference model needs specified inside quotation marks first assigned name like :pass model text sem function lavaan:model now stored TEMP_WIND_fit. One way learn model use parameterEstimates function.lot output , â€™re going talk now. Focus â€œestâ€ column.recognize three estimates. Explain numbers represent.particular, pay close attention second line. hasty, may think variance \(Y\), correct.can also produce standardized estimates., explain three numbers. (now listed column called est.std â€œstandardized estimatesâ€.)Verify second line actually error variance. (Hint: remember \(1 - r_{XY}^{2}\).) know â€™s standardized variance \(Y\)? (words, actually know standardized variance \(Y\)?)
code:
TEMP_WIND_model <- "Y ~ X" 
TEMP_WIND_fit <- sem(TEMP_WIND_model, data = airquality_mc)
parameterEstimates(TEMP_WIND_fit)##   lhs op rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
## 1   Y  ~   X -1.230 0.193 -6.373      0   -1.609   -0.852
## 2   Y ~~   Y 70.337 8.042  8.746      0   54.575   86.098
## 3   X ~~   X 12.330 0.000     NA     NA   12.330   12.330
standardizedSolution(TEMP_WIND_fit)##   lhs op rhs est.std    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
## 1   Y  ~   X  -0.458 0.060 -7.577      0   -0.576   -0.340
## 2   Y ~~   Y   0.790 0.055 14.273      0    0.682    0.899
## 3   X ~~   X   1.000 0.000     NA     NA    1.000    1.000

heading: 5.2 Multiple regression assumptions
5.3 Calculating regression parameters
text:
nothing new , calculations start get little messy. Everything follows two predictors . calculations three predictors. gets hand pretty quickly.First, letâ€™s remember â€™re trying . data, can calculate sample covariance matrix. variances covariances among observed variables:\[
\begin{bmatrix}
Var(X_{1})  &   Cov(X_{1}, X_{2})   &   Cov(X_{1}, Y) \\
\bullet     &   Var(X_{2})          &   Cov(X_{2}, Y) \\
\bullet     &   \bullet             &   Var(Y)
\end{bmatrix}
\]Remember entries just numbers calculate directly data.get started model-implied matrix, letâ€™s extend Rule 12 little.three variables \(X_{1}\), \(X_{2}\), \(X_{3}\):\[\begin{align}
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2} + cX_{3}) &=
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + c^2Var(X_{3}) \\
    & \quad + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2}) \\
    & \quad + 2acCov(X_{1}, X_{3}) \\
    & \quad + 2bcCov(X_{2}, X_{3})
\end{align}\]can extended number variables. variance appears coefficient squared pair variables gets covariance term 2 times product corresponding variable coefficients. (â€™s hard describe words, â€™s still trouble â€™s worth writing formal mathematical notation. Hopefully can see pattern coefficients generalizes.)Now can compute, example, \(Var(Y)\):\[\begin{align}
Var(Y)  &= Var(b_{1}X_{1} + b_{2}X_{2} + E) \\
    &= b_{1}^{2} Var(X_{1}) + b_{2}^{2} Var(X_{2}) + Var(E) \\
    & \quad + 2b_{1}b_{2} Cov(X_{1}, X_{2}) \\
    & \quad + 2b_{1} Cov(X_{1}, E) \\
    & \quad + 2b_{2} Cov(X_{2}, E)
\end{align}\]happens last two lines ? ?Therefore,\[
Var(Y) = b_{1}^{2} v_{1} + b_{2}^{2} v_{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} c_{12} + e
\]Rule 8 Rule 9 work way, â€™s even easier apply. Just split covariance many pieces terms split.turn.Calculate \(Cov(X_{1}, Y)\). get\[
b_{1} v_{1} + b_{2} c_{12}
\]
Calculate \(Cov(X_{2}, Y)\). get\[
b_{2} v_{2} + b_{1} c_{12}
\]turns computation need write model-implied matrix.first three entries easy just parameters \(v_{1}\), \(c_{12}\), \(v_{2}\). last column contains entries just calculated .Therefore, model-implied matrix \[
\begin{bmatrix}
v_{1}   &    c_{12}  &   b_{1} v_{1} + b_{2} c_{12} \\
\bullet &    v_{2}   &   b_{2} v_{2} + b_{1} c_{12} \\
\bullet &    \bullet &   b_{1}^{2} v_{1} + b_{2}^{2} v_{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} c_{12} + e
\end{bmatrix}
\]
set expressions equal numbers sample covariance matrix, theory solve unknown parameters model-implied matrix . Three basically already done since can just read \(v_{1}\), \(c_{12}\), \(v_{2}\). solving \(b_{1}\), \(b_{2}\), \(e\) joke! even , resulting expressions particularly enlightening. quite happy turning computational details computer.

Suppose think college GPA can predicted using high school GPA along number hours per week spent studying college. model might look like:high school GPA hours per week studying correlated (likely ), influence , influence danger â€œcorruptingâ€ estimates path coefficients. example, \(b_{2}\) positive, suggest hours spend studying associated predicted increases college GPA. know â€™s really due studying? Maybe students well high school just â€œsmarterâ€. Sure, also put hours studying, maybe doesnâ€™t matter. Maybe students just well college even didnâ€™t study whole lot. case, coefficient \(b_{2}\) positive just set students (happen study , even though doesnâ€™t matter) also ones high college GPAs.â€™s important control variables. means need temporarily fix value variables make comparison fair. example, look students 3.0 high school. Among students, variability number hours study college. variability associated variability college GPA, know hours spent studying least partly â€œresponsibleâ€ explaining change. (lots factors , swept error variance.) high school GPA canâ€™t explain fixed 3.0, â€™re comparing apples apples. Students got 2.0 high school may poorly overall, relative increase GPA due studying .parameter \(b_{2}\) estimated 0.13, suggests additional hour study time per week predicts increase 0.13 points college GPA, holding high school GPA constant. means increase 0.13 predicted among groups students high school GPA.Letâ€™s say \(b_{1}\) estimated 1.2. means college GPA predicted increase 1.2 points every point increase high school GPA. multiple regression model, coefficient can interpreting holding HOURS constant. means coefficient holds among groups students put number hours studying. takes hours studying explanation accounts changes high school GPA.

heading: 5.5 Regression with standardized variables
text:
Things get little easier (although completely trivial) standardized variables.First, notational simplification. correlations variablesâ€”according conventionâ€”called \(r_{X_{1}X_{2}}\), \(r_{X_{1}Y}\), \(r_{X_{2}Y}\). little hard look complex expressions, replace \(r_{12}\), \(r_{1Y}\), \(r_{2Y}\).Letâ€™s look sample covariance matrix model-implied matrix standardized variables:\[
\begin{bmatrix}
1           &   r_{12}      &   r_{1Y} \\
\bullet     &   1           &   r_{2Y} \\
\bullet     &   \bullet     &   1
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
v_{1}   &    c_{12}  &   b_{1} v_{1} + b_{2} c_{12} \\
\bullet &    v_{2}   &   b_{2} v_{2} + b_{1} c_{12} \\
\bullet &    \bullet &   b_{1}^{2} v_{1} + b_{2}^{2} v_{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} c_{12} + e
\end{bmatrix}
\]
entry upper-right corner yields\[
r_{1Y} = b_{1} v_{1} + b_{2} c_{12}
\]
simplifies 
\[
r_{1Y} = b_{1} + b_{2} r_{12}
\]
next entry yields\[
r_{2Y} = b_{2} v_{2} + b_{1} c_{12}
\]
simplifies 
\[
r_{2Y} = b_{2} + b_{1} r_{12}
\]two equations can solved two unknown parameters \(b_{1}\) \(b_{2}\).feeling brave? algebra skills sharp? Totally optional, see can derive final answers :\[
b_{1} = \frac{r_{1Y} - r_{2Y}r_{12}}{1 - r_{12}^{2}}
\]\[
b_{2} = \frac{r_{2Y} - r_{1Y}r_{12}}{1 - r_{12}^{2}}
\]still pretty gross, intuitive content . Look numerator fraction \(b_{1}\). Essentially, just \(r_{1Y}\) extra stuff. simple regression, expect slope \(b_{1}\) simply correlation \(X_{1}\) \(Y\). multiple regression, also control contribution model coming \(X_{2}\). ? subtracting contribution, turns \(r_{2Y}r_{12}\). latter term appear way ? need control effect \(X_{2}\) \(X_{2}\) providing â€œinformationâ€ regression model \(X_{1}\). Therefore, donâ€™t need subtract \(r_{2Y}\) control \(X_{2}\), just fraction \(r_{2Y}\). just need part \(X_{2}\) common \(X_{1}\). donâ€™t want â€œdouble-countâ€ contribution model common \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\).â€™s another way think . \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent? Calculate \(b_{1}\) \(b_{2}\) formulas much easier case. (Donâ€™t overthink . \(r_{12}\) case?)\(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, offer unique contribution predicting \(Y\) model. contribution just correlation \(Y\) (\(r_{1Y}\) \(r_{2Y}\), respectively). overlap. \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) correlated, â€œinfluenceâ€ counted twice. subtract influence \(b_{1}\) \(b_{2}\) measuring â€œpureâ€ contribution \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\), controlling one.\(1 - r_{12}^{2}\) denominator? â€™s less good intuitive explanation . â€™s â€”mathematically speakingâ€”. rescales slope coefficients make everything work way .final equation one \(Var(Y)\) lower-right corner matrix. says\[
1 = b_{1}^{2} v_{1} + b_{2}^{2} v_{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} c_{12} + e
\]
simplifies 
\[
1 = b_{1}^{2} + b_{2}^{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} r_{12} + e
\]
Rearranging solve \(e\),
\[
e = 1 - \left(b_{1}^{2} + b_{2}^{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} r_{12}\right)
\]
enlightening way replace \(b_{1}\) \(b_{2}\) earlier fractions. can leave \(e\) like .Since variance \(Y\) 1, stuff inside parentheses represents variance explained model. (subtracted 1, , left \(e\), error variance.) analogous \(R^{2}\) term described last chapter.makes conceptual sense . pieces \(\left(b_{1}^{2} + b_{2}^{2} + 2b_{1}b_{2} r_{12}\right)\) correspond various pieces model. first two relate direct effects \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) third piece relates â€œindirectâ€ effect shared .

heading: 5.6 Multiple regression in R
text:
Letâ€™s fit multiple regression model data music. data sample 10,000 songs Million Song Dataset, collection metrics audio million contemporary popular music tracks.data set downloaded CORGIS Dataset Project information variables data set can found .endogenous variable interest us measure songâ€™s popularity, called song.hotttnesss (scale 0 1).16 many possible exogenous predictors, letâ€™s focus three:artist.hotttnesss
popularity artist (scale 0 1).
popularity artist (scale 0 1).song.loudness
clear website exactly, appears kind average dBFS (decibels relative full scale). Numbers close zero actually loud recordings reasonably go increasingly negative numbers represent softer volumes.
clear website exactly, appears kind average dBFS (decibels relative full scale). Numbers close zero actually loud recordings reasonably go increasingly negative numbers represent softer volumes.song.tempo
measured beats per minute (BPM).
measured beats per minute (BPM).

music <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/VectorPosse/sem_book/main/data/music.csv")## Rows: 10000 Columns: 35
## â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
## Delimiter: ","

##

Just use plus signs right side tilde ~ add predictors.didnâ€™t go trouble mean-centering data time, intercept longer 0. attempt interpret intercept anyway. three coefficients \(b_{1}\), \(b_{2}\) \(b_{3}\), path coefficients model. interpreted follows:\(b_{1}\):
Song popularity predicted increase 1.157 points every point increase artist popularity.
Song popularity predicted increase 1.157 points every point increase artist popularity.mathematically true, â€™s kind nonsensical report using numbers magnitude. scales go 0 1, increase 1 point measuring difference artist 0 popularity (least popular artists data set) artist 1 popularity (popular artists data set).better way report scale everything factor 10:Song popularity predicted increase 0.1157 points every 0.1 increase artist popularity.Song popularity predicted increase 0.1157 points every 0.1 increase artist popularity.\(b_{2}\):
Song popularity predicted increase 0.01187 points every increase 1 dB loudness.

heading: 5.6.2 Using lavaan
text: Model specification lavaan happens separate step.model fit sem function.unstandardized parameter estimates:Focus estimate column (est).recognize values lines 1 3?line 4 mean? (Hint: â€™s variance song.hotttnesss even though notation makes look like .)â€™s going lines 5 10?standardized parameter estimates:Focus estimates (est.std).easier compare values lines 1 though 3 output unstandardized table? (Hint: think units measurement lack thereof.)value line 4 tell ? (Hint: â€™s awfully close 1.)lines 5, 8, 10 equal 1?interpret lines 6, 7, 9?final model variables labeled unstandardized parameter estimates identified:thing, standardized parameter estimates:
code:
SONG_model <- "song.hotttnesss ~ artist.hotttnesss +
    song.loudness + 
    song.tempo" 
SONG_fit <- sem(SONG_model, data = music)

heading: A Variance/covariance rules
text:
Rule 1If \(C\) constant, \[
Var\left(C\right) = 0
\]Rule 2If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Var\left(X_{1} + X_{2}\right) =
Var\left(X_{1}\right) + Var\left(X_{2}\right)
\]Consequence Rule 1 Rule 2:\[
Var\left(X + C\right) = Var\left(X\right)
\]Rule 3If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Var\left(X_{1} - X_{2}\right) =
Var\left(X_{1}\right) + Var\left(X_{2}\right)
\]Rule 4If \(\) number,\[
Var\left(aX\right) = ^2 Var\left(X\right)
\]Rule 5\[
Cov(X, X) = Var(X)
\]Rule 6\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{1}\right)
\]Rule 7If \(C\) constant, \[
Cov\left(X, C\right) = 0
\]Rule 8\[
Cov\left(X_{1} + X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) + Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Rule 9\[
Cov\left(X_{1} - X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) - Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Consequence Rule 6, Rule 8, Rule 9:\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2} \pm X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) \pm Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Rule 10If \(\) number,\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) =  Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)  
\]Rule 11If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = 0
\]Rule 12For two variables \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\):\[
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) =
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]three variables \(X_{1}\), \(X_{2}\), \(X_{3}\):\[\begin{align}
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2} + cX_{3}) &=
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + c^2Var(X_{3}) \\
    & \quad + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2}) \\
    & \quad + 2acCov(X_{1}, X_{3}) \\
    & \quad + 2bcCov(X_{2}, X_{3})
\end{align}\]can extended number variables. variance appears coefficient squared pair variables gets covariance term 2 times product corresponding variable coefficients.
